title: 112_s1527
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Congress finds that President Franklin D. Roosevelt issued Executive Order No. 8802, allowing African-American individuals to enlist in the Marine Corps. The first African-American Marine recruits were trained at Camp Montford Point in North Carolina, with Howard P. Perry being the first African-American private to set foot there. In April 1943, the first African-American Marine drill instructors took over as senior drill instructors of the platoons in training. African-American Marines landed on Iwo Jima on D-Day, February 19, 1945. They also participated in the seizure of Okinawa during World War II. Frederick C. Branch was the first African-American Marine commissioned as a Second Lieutenant on November 10, 1945. African-American Marine to be commissioned as a Second Lieutenant at Marine Base in Quantico, Virginia; 19,168 African-Americans served in the Marine Corps in World War II. 16 years after Montford Point closure, a reunion of Montford Point Marines was organized by original Master Sergeant Brooks E. Gray in 1965, laying the foundation for the Montford Point Marine Association Inc., a nonmilitary, nonprofit entity dedicated to preserving the legacy of the first African-American Marines. The Montford Point Marine Association preserves the legacy of the first African-American Marines with 36 chapters in the US. Sergeant Major Edgar R. Huff, one of the first recruits at Montford Point, had a distinguished career in the Marine Corps, serving in World War II, the Korean Conflict, and the Vietnam War. He was the first African-American Sergeant Major and retired after 30 years of service, receiving the Bronze Star medal for valor during the Tet Offensive in Vietnam. Another Montford Point Marine also saw combat in the Korean Conflict and Vietnam War. Sergeant Major Louis Roundtree, a Montford Point Marine, received multiple awards for his service in the Korean Conflict and Vietnam War. Montford Point was renamed Camp Johnson in honor of Sergeant Major Gilbert Johnson. The Montford Point Marine Association has memorials, including the Edgar R. Huff Memorial Scholarship and the Montford Point Museum. The Montford Point Marine Association has memorials at Camp Johnson in North Carolina, including the Montford Point Museum, the Brooks Elbert Gray, Jr. Consolidated Academic Instruction Facility, and Branch Hall in Quantico, Virginia. Branch Hall was named in honor of Captain Frederick Branch in 1997. The Montford Point Marine Association has memorials at Camp Johnson in North Carolina and Branch Hall in Quantico, Virginia. Branch Hall was named in honor of Captain Frederick Branch in 1997. Congressional Gold Medal. The Montford Point Marines, United States Marine Corps, will be awarded a single gold medal by the Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate in recognition of their service during World War II. The gold medal will be designed and struck by the Secretary of the Treasury and then displayed at the Smithsonian Institution. The gold medal awarded to the Montford Point Marines will be displayed at the Smithsonian Institution and should also be available for display at other locations associated with the Marines. The Secretary may strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal in bronze, with proceeds deposited in the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund. Medals struck under this Act are considered national medals. Authorization of appropriations not to exceed $30,000 is granted for the medal's cost, with sales proceeds also going to the Fund.
